body: additionally to my above request, I would expect psalm to error, because `strpos()` can never return `-1` (this can be a common mistake, because people might be used to javascript in which the equivalent function returns -1)

issue.title: Added more fine grained strpos stub

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
A shot in the dark.. Might fix the comment https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/issues/4070#issuecomment-680942551

> I would expect psalm to error, because strpos() can never return -1 (this can be a common mistake, because people might be used to javascript in which the equivalent function returns -1)

https://psalm.dev/r/22d89c087e

body: Hmm wondering why I dont get a error on https://psalm.dev/r/e0c5b3e258 after you fixed this issue?
@muglug could you re-open the issue, as it seems not to be fixed atm?

> I can't think of a good use-case where I want the $haystack to be a string literal.

This does cause false positives in the code that uses strings as lookup tables (we have quite a few of those for generating barcodes). Can we make the issue more specific, so that it could be selectively suppressed?

> Can we make the issue more specific, so that it could be selectively suppressed?

Sure, I'll do that

> This does cause false positives in the code that uses strings as lookup tables (we have quite a few of those for generating barcodes)

@weirdan Im curios.. could younshow a example for what you are talking about?

@muglug its working now, thx for fixing

One question!

https://psalm.dev/r/22d89c087e

Outputs

> ERROR: DocblockTypeContradiction - 8:7 - int can never contain false|int|int

Shouldnt it be

> ERROR: DocblockTypeContradiction - 8:7 - int can never contain positive-int|0|false

?

> Im curios.. could younshow a example for what you are talking about?

Sure. E.g. [Codabar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Codabar) encoding may look like this: https://psalm.dev/r/ffe1e64c0f
@weirdan I think I can add an explicit check for strings with sequential characters, saw a similar false-positive in Vimeo's codebase
